title: I stopped paying HOA fees (California) 7/2007. Unit foreclosed 9/2008. I got sued by HOA 7/2012 for $3450. Is SOL covering me?
question: Is the breach of contract running from 7/2012 (where I stopped paying) or from 9/2008 (Foreclosure date)?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Residential property,HOA disputes,HOA fees,Foreclosure,Homeowners' association,Lawsuits and disputes
answers: Attorney Chen is correct, you need to get some legal advice on this one, or try and reach a settlement or resolution with the HOA Creditor's attorney.
Have the complaint reviewed by an atty to see what they allege, and if there is any defense.

Not necessarily. While the general statute of limitations for breach of written contract is four years from breach or date of last payment (whichever is later), the HOA might be able to argue a 5 year statute of limitations applies. In California, HOAs are governed by the Davis-Stirling Common Interest Development Act. Arguably, a court could allow a 5 year statute of limitations as a breach of an equitable servitude. Pursuant to California Code of Civil Procedure section 336(b), the statute of limitations for violation of a CC&R provision or a rule is 5 years from the time the HOA board discovers the violation or, through the exercise of reasonable diligence, should have discovered the violation. So, unless you file for bankruptcy to discharge such debts, you are not necessarily off the hook for the unpaid HOA assessments.
